title: How to Boil Eggs in a Rice Cooker

steps.headline: Add the water.
steps.description: Add about a cup of water into the rice cooker.

steps.headline: Insert the steam rack or basket in the cooker.
steps.description: Some rice cooker models have an attachment basket available to use, as this works as well.

steps.headline: Add the eggs onto the basket.
steps.description: Make sure that they stand upright, so the bottom of them is down. This will balance out the yolks and be the ideal finish if you are making deviled eggs.

steps.headline: Cover the cooker with a lid.
steps.description: It's important not to lift the lid on during the cooking process, or else all of the steam will escape.

steps.headline: Cook the eggs.
steps.description: Push down the rice cooker button and set the time for 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Prepare your rice.
steps.description: Many Japanese rice brands suggest rinsing the rice out, but it is completely optional.

steps.headline: Fill the rice cooker with water.
steps.description: Depending how many cups of rice you are making, add a half cup more of water.

steps.headline: Add the eggs onto the rice grains.
steps.description: Make sure that they stand upright, so the bottom of them is down. This will balance out the yolks and be the ideal finish if you are making deviled eggs.

steps.headline: Cover the cooker with a lid.
steps.description: It's important not to lift the lid on during the cooking process, or else all of the steam will escape.

steps.headline: Cook the eggs and rice.
steps.description: Push down the rice cooker button and allow the rice to completely cook.

steps.headline: Make an ice bath.
steps.description: In a large bowl, add cold water and ice cubes so that it fills up to the rim.

steps.headline: Remove the eggs from the rice cooker.
steps.description: Use plastic or metal tongs to remove them from the rice cooker, one by one. Immediately place them in the ice bath.

steps.headline: Serve or store them.
steps.description: Allow the eggs to completely cool in the ice bath. You can test them out by handling them with your fingers. Serve them immediately or store them in the refrigerator.

text: Boiling by Themselves Add the water. Add about a cup of water into the rice cooker. Insert the steam rack or basket in the cooker. Some rice cooker models have an attachment basket available to use, as this works as well. Add the eggs onto the basket. Make sure that they stand upright, so the bottom of them is down. This will balance out the yolks and be the ideal finish if you are making deviled eggs. Cover the cooker with a lid. It's important not to lift the lid on during the cooking process, or else all of the steam will escape. Cook the eggs. Push down the rice cooker button and set the time for 20 minutes. Boiling Them with Rice Prepare your rice. Many Japanese rice brands suggest rinsing the rice out, but it is completely optional. Fill the rice cooker with water. Depending how many cups of rice you are making, add a half cup more of water. Add the eggs onto the rice grains. Make sure that they stand upright, so the bottom of them is down. This will balance out the yolks and be the ideal finish if you are making deviled eggs. Cover the cooker with a lid. It's important not to lift the lid on during the cooking process, or else all of the steam will escape. Cook the eggs and rice. Push down the rice cooker button and allow the rice to completely cook. Finishing the Eggs Make an ice bath. In a large bowl, add cold water and ice cubes so that it fills up to the rim. Remove the eggs from the rice cooker. Use plastic or metal tongs to remove them from the rice cooker, one by one. Immediately place them in the ice bath. Serve or store them. Allow the eggs to completely cool in the ice bath. You can test them out by handling them with your fingers. Serve them immediately or store them in the refrigerator. Finished.
